awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation: Computational thinking in Biological Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The amount of data available to inform medicine and biology is growing at an incredible rate and new technologies and methods are needed to integrate and effectively utilize the data.  Bioengineering needs to produce well-trained graduates to meet future demand for experts in the field. To meet this growing need, this research program: 1) improves undergraduate Bioengineering education by changing how we teach data analysis and mathematical modeling, 2) maps the growth of students' understanding of computational concepts over time, and 3) will identify factors that lead to lower participation among women and other underrepresented minorities in these types of data and computer-focused problems. The program is designed to identify the best way to teach all aspiring bioengineers to excel at computational tasks such as how to build diagrams that connect data together or how to use a computer to make meaningful predictions based on data.

The project team will use an existing curricular structure to initiate an engineering education research project that investigates the professional formation of engineers. Specifically, we have three objectives: (1) to characterize the progression of computational thinking in undergraduate biomedical engineering students from novice to expert over 3 courses; (2) to examine the intersection between gender, engineering identity, and computational thinking; and (3) to iteratively improve the undergraduate curricula to promote growth in computational thinking for all Bioengineers. The interdisciplinary research team brings together expertise in computational modeling, and deep methodological and pedagogical methods. To ensure long-lasting impact, this work will also train faculty in the scholarship of Engineering Education at Purdue. Additionally, the PI will act as a connector between the engineering education community and the computational tool-building life sciences research community to promote mutually beneficial exchange of ideas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes report

 

The goal of this project was to investigate the professional formation of engineers in an undergraduate Bioengineering program. Specifically, we sought to track students’ growth in understanding computational concepts over time as well as among women and other underrepresented minorities. Through this analysis we seek to improve the teaching of computational and data analysis topics.

 

Our specific objectives were to 1) characterize the progression of computational thinking in undergraduate biomedical engineering students from novice to expert over 3 courses; (2) examine the intersection between gender, engineering identity, and computational thinking; and (3) iteratively improve the undergraduate curricula to promote growth in computational thinking for all Bioengineers.

 

Through surveys and interviews with students in an undergraduate Thermodynamics course over two years, we found lower pre-course computational self-efficacy (CSE) in women than men. Our data indicate that gendered differences in both preference for, and assignment to technical roles in team projects. Our analysis showed that discipline-based computational instruction can increase CSE for women, but that this increase in CSE does not lead to greater preference for, or assignment to, technical roles in team projects. Instead role preference and assignment appears to be a socially mediated process that is influenced by perceived gendered differences in competence rather than the actual CSE of the participants.

 

Another factor in students’ experiences in computationally intensive courses relates to their computational identity – i.e. how much they identify as a “computational person”. Through student interviews students expressed a perceived dis-connect between identifying as a “computational person” vs. identifying as a “creative person” or a woman.

 

Taken together, our work has shown that computationally focused teaching can help close the gap in CSE between men and women. We also identified social factors and personal identity perceptions that can serve as barriers to participation for women in computationally intensive projects. By identifying these barriers, we can now design course activities that support students’ technical growth as well as strengthen their computational identity and computational self-efficacy.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/21/2022
Modified by: David Umulis

Project outcomes report

Our analysis showed that discipline-based computational instruction can increase CSE for women, but that this increase in CSE does not lead to greater preference for, or assignment to, technical roles in team projects. By identifying these barriers, we can now design course activities that support students’ technical growth as well as strengthen their computational identity and computational self-efficacy.
